com.mesosphere.sdk.offer.evaluate.placement

Class MarathonConstraintParser

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.mesosphere.sdk.offer.evaluate.placement.MarathonConstraintParser

  • public final class MarathonConstraintParser
extends java.lang.Object
    Implements support for generating PlacementRules from Marathon-style constraint strings.
    See Also:
    Marathon Constraints

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Static Methods Concrete Methods

      • Methods inherited from class java.lang.Object

        clone, equals, finalize, getClass, hashCode, notify, notifyAll, toString, wait, wait, wait

    • Method Detail

      • parse

        public static PlacementRule parse(java.lang.String podName,
                                  java.lang.String marathonConstraints)
        Creates and returns a new PlacementRule against the provided marathon-style constraint string. Returns a PassthroughRule if the provided constraint string is null or empty.
        Parameters:
        podName - The task type these constraints apply to (e.g. "hello"). Applying a constraint to all tasks in a service is not supported.
        marathonConstraints - the marathon-style constraint string, containing one or more nested json list entries of the form [["multi","list","value"],["hello","hi"]], or one or more colon-separated entries of the form multi:list:value,hello:hi, or a null or empty value if no constraint is defined

      • splitConstraints

        static java.util.List<java.util.List<java.lang.String>> splitConstraints(java.lang.String marathonConstraints)
        Splits the provided marathon constraint statement into elements. Doesn't do any validation on the element contents.

      • escapedSplit

        static java.util.Collection<java.lang.String> escapedSplit(java.lang.String str,
                                                           char split)
        Tokenizes the provided string using the provided split character. Honors any backslash escaping within the provided string. Tokens in the returned list are automatically trimmed.

        This is equivalent to calling Splitter.on(split).trimResults().split(str), except with the addition of support for escaping the 'split' value with backslashes.
